A equa√ß√£o que descreve essa for√ßa de desbalanceamento √© dada por:
\begin{equation*}
\begin{split}F_u = m_u \cdot e \cdot \omega^2 \sin(\omega t)\end{split}
\end{equation*}
\sphinxAtStartPar
onde \(m_u\) √© a massa desbalanceada, \(e\) √© a excentricidade, e \(\omega\) √© a velocidade angular.

\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxstylestrong{Sinais Aleat√≥rios (ou Estoc√°sticos):} Em contraste, s√£o sinais cujo valor futuro n√£o pode ser previsto com exatid√£o a partir de seus valores passados. Eles n√£o seguem um padr√£o repetitivo e devem ser caracterizados por suas propriedades estat√≠sticas, como m√©dia (\(\mu\)), vari√¢ncia (\(\sigma^2\)) e densidade espectral de pot√™ncia (\(S_{xx}(f)\)). Exemplos comuns incluem o ru√≠do t√©rmico em um circuito eletr√¥nico, a turbul√™ncia de um fluido ou as ondas do mar que atuam sobre um navio {[}\hyperlink{cite.aula_01/motivacao:id7}{2}{]}.


\section{O Paradoxo da An√°lise Aleat√≥ria}
\label{\detokenize{aula_01/motivacao:o-paradoxo-da-analise-aleatoria}}
\sphinxAtStartPar
A natureza imprevis√≠vel dos sinais aleat√≥rios levanta uma quest√£o fundamental: se n√£o podemos prever o que acontecer√° no pr√≥ximo instante, qual o prop√≥sito de analis√°\sphinxhyphen{}los? A resposta, como elucidado pelo professor Duarte, n√£o est√° no sinal em si, mas na sua intera√ß√£o com um sistema din√¢mico.

\sphinxAtStartPar
Um sistema din√¢mico √© qualquer sistema f√≠sico que possui a capacidade de armazenar e dissipar energia. Seus componentes fundamentais s√£o massa (que armazena energia cin√©tica), rigidez (que armazena energia potencial) e amortecimento (que dissipa energia). O comportamento desses sistemas √© governado por leis f√≠sicas, como a Segunda Lei de Newton, que afirma que a somat√≥ria das for√ßas √© igual √† massa vezes a acelera√ß√£o:
\begin{equation*}
\begin{split}\sum F = m \cdot a\end{split}
\end{equation*}

\section{O Sistema Din√¢mico como um Filtro Natural}
\label{\detokenize{aula_01/motivacao:o-sistema-dinamico-como-um-filtro-natural}}
\sphinxAtStartPar
Quando um sinal aleat√≥rio atua como uma excita√ß√£o (entrada) para um sistema din√¢mico, o sistema n√£o responde de forma totalmente aleat√≥ria. Em vez disso, ele atua como um filtro, moldando a resposta (sa√≠da) de acordo com suas pr√≥prias caracter√≠sticas intr√≠nsecas.

\sphinxAtStartPar
Este conceito de ‚Äúfiltragem‚Äù ocorre porque todo sistema din√¢mico possui frequ√™ncias naturais (ou modos de vibra√ß√£o), que s√£o as frequ√™ncias nas quais o sistema tende a oscilar com maior amplitude quando perturbado. Quando o sinal de entrada aleat√≥rio, que pode ser considerado como contendo um amplo espectro de frequ√™ncias (ru√≠do branco, por exemplo), atravessa o sistema, as componentes de frequ√™ncia pr√≥ximas √†s frequ√™ncias naturais do sistema s√£o amplificadas, enquanto outras s√£o atenuadas {[}\hyperlink{cite.aula_01/motivacao:id8}{3}{]}.

\sphinxAtStartPar
Matematicamente, em um contexto digital, a resposta do sistema em um instante \(k\), \(x[k]\), depende dos valores passados da resposta e da excita√ß√£o. Uma forma discretizada da equa√ß√£o do movimento pode ser expressa como uma equa√ß√£o de diferen√ßas:
\begin{equation*}
\begin{split}x[k] = f(x[k-1], x[k-2], ..., u[k], u[k-1], ...)\end{split}
\end{equation*}
\sphinxAtStartPar
onde \(x[k]\) √© a resposta no instante \(k\) e \(u[k]\) √© a excita√ß√£o. Esta depend√™ncia do passado √© a pr√≥pria defini√ß√£o de um filtro digital. A opera√ß√£o que descreve a intera√ß√£o entre o sinal de entrada e a resposta do sistema no dom√≠nio do tempo √© a \sphinxstylestrong{convolu√ß√£o}:
\begin{equation*}
\begin{split}y(t) = \int_{-\infty}^{\infty} h(\tau) x(t-\tau) d\tau\end{split}
\end{equation*}
\sphinxAtStartPar
onde \(h(t)\) √© a resposta ao impulso do sistema.


\section{Da Aleatoriedade √† An√°lise Estat√≠stica Estruturada}
\label{\detokenize{aula_01/motivacao:da-aleatoriedade-a-analise-estatistica-estruturada}}
\sphinxAtStartPar
O resultado deste processo √© que o sinal de sa√≠da, embora ainda possua um car√°ter aleat√≥rio, n√£o √© mais ‚Äútotalmente bagun√ßado‚Äù. Ele carrega a ‚Äúassinatura‚Äù do sistema din√¢mico pelo qual passou. As frequ√™ncias dominantes no sinal de resposta correspondem √†s frequ√™ncias naturais do sistema.

\sphinxAtStartPar
Portanto, ao analisar estatisticamente o sinal de resposta ‚Äî por exemplo, calculando sua \sphinxstylestrong{Densidade Espectral de Pot√™ncia} (PSD):
\begin{equation*}
\begin{split}S_{yy}(f) = |H(f)|^2 S_{xx}(f)\end{split}
\end{equation*}
\sphinxAtStartPar
onde \(S_{xx}(f)\) √© a PSD do sinal de entrada e \(H(f)\) √© a fun√ß√£o de transfer√™ncia do sistema ‚Äî podemos identificar esses picos de energia e, a partir deles, inferir propriedades cr√≠ticas do sistema f√≠sico, como sua rigidez, amortecimento e poss√≠veis danos estruturais {[}\hyperlink{cite.aula_01/motivacao:id9}{4}{]}. √â assim que a an√°lise de vibra√ß√µes em uma ponte excitada pelo vento (sinal aleat√≥rio) pode revelar sua sa√∫de estrutural.


\section{Conclus√£o}
\label{\detokenize{aula_01/motivacao:conclusao}}
\sphinxAtStartPar
A an√°lise de sinais aleat√≥rios, longe de ser um exerc√≠cio f√∫til, √© uma ferramenta poderosa para entender o mundo f√≠sico. A chave para desvendar a informa√ß√£o contida em um sinal aparentemente ca√≥tico √© reconhecer o papel fundamental dos sistemas din√¢micos. Ao atuarem como filtros naturais, esses sistemas imp√µem uma ordem √† aleatoriedade, permitindo que, atrav√©s de ferramentas estat√≠sticas, possamos extrair informa√ß√µes valiosas sobre suas pr√≥prias caracter√≠sticas. A aparente imprevisibilidade da entrada se transforma em conhecimento sobre o sistema, tornando a an√°lise de sinais aleat√≥rios um pilar essencial para o diagn√≥stico de falhas, o monitoramento de estruturas e o projeto de sistemas robustos.


\section{Refer√™ncias}
\label{\detokenize{aula_01/motivacao:referencias}}
\sphinxstepscope


\chapter{Signals}
\label{\detokenize{aula_01/signals:signals}}\label{\detokenize{aula_01/signals::doc}}

\section{Definition of Signals}
\label{\detokenize{aula_01/signals:definition-of-signals}}
\sphinxAtStartPar
A \sphinxstylestrong{signal} is a function that carries information about a physical phenomenon {[}\hyperlink{cite.aula_01/signals:id7}{1}{]}. In the context of signals and systems, we typically deal with signals that vary with time.

\sphinxAtStartPar
Mathematically, a signal can be represented as:
\begin{equation*}
\begin{split}x(t) \quad \text{for continuous-time signals}\end{split}
\end{equation*}\begin{equation*}
\begin{split}x[n] \quad \text{for discrete-time signals}\end{split}
\end{equation*}
\sphinxAtStartPar
where:
\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
\(t\) is a continuous variable (time)

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
\(n\) is a discrete variable (sample number)

\end{itemize}


\section{Classification of Signals}
\label{\detokenize{aula_01/signals:classification-of-signals}}

\subsection{Continuous\sphinxhyphen{}time vs Discrete\sphinxhyphen{}time}
\label{\detokenize{aula_01/signals:continuous-time-vs-discrete-time}}
\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxstylestrong{Continuous\sphinxhyphen{}time signals} are defined for all values of time \(t\) in a continuous interval.

\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxstylestrong{Discrete\sphinxhyphen{}time signals} are defined only at discrete time instants, typically at regular intervals.


\subsection{Analog vs Digital}
\label{\detokenize{aula_01/signals:analog-vs-digital}}\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxstylestrong{Analog signals}: Continuous in both time and amplitude

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxstylestrong{Digital signals}: Discrete in both time and amplitude

\end{itemize}


\subsection{Periodic vs Aperiodic}
\label{\detokenize{aula_01/signals:periodic-vs-aperiodic}}
\sphinxAtStartPar
A signal \(x(t)\) is \sphinxstylestrong{periodic} if there exists a positive constant \(T\) such that:
\begin{equation*}
\begin{split}x(t) = x(t + T) \quad \text{for all } t\end{split}
\end{equation*}
\sphinxAtStartPar
The smallest such \(T\) is called the \sphinxstylestrong{fundamental period}.


\subsection{Even vs Odd}
\label{\detokenize{aula_01/signals:even-vs-odd}}
\sphinxAtStartPar
A signal is \sphinxstylestrong{even} if:
\begin{equation*}
\begin{split}x(t) = x(-t)\end{split}
\end{equation*}

\sphinxAtStartPar
A signal is \sphinxstylestrong{odd} if:
\begin{equation*}
\begin{split}x(t) = -x(-t)\end{split}
\end{equation*}


\section{Common Signals}
\label{\detokenize{aula_01/signals:common-signals}}

\subsection{Unit Step Function}
\label{\detokenize{aula_01/signals:unit-step-function}}\begin{equation*}
\begin{split}u(t) = \begin{cases}
1 & \text{if } t \geq 0 \\
0 & \text{if } t < 0
\end{cases}\end{split}
\end{equation*}

\subsection{Unit Impulse Function (Dirac Delta)}
\label{\detokenize{aula_01/signals:unit-impulse-function-dirac-delta}}\begin{equation*}
\begin{split}\delta(t) = \begin{cases}
\infty & \text{if } t = 0 \\
0 & \text{if } t \neq 0
\end{cases}\end{split}
\end{equation*}
\sphinxAtStartPar
with the property:
\begin{equation*}
\begin{split}\int_{-\infty}^{\infty} \delta(t) \, dt = 1\end{split}
\end{equation*}


\subsection{Sinusoidal Signals}
\label{\detokenize{aula_01/signals:sinusoidal-signals}}\begin{equation*}
\begin{split}x(t) = A \cos(\omega t + \phi)\end{split}
\end{equation*}
\sphinxAtStartPar
where:
\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
\(A\) is the amplitude

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
\(\omega\) is the angular frequency (rad/s)

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
\(\phi\) is the phase (rad)

\end{itemize}


\section{Interactive Examples}
\label{\detokenize{aula_01/signals:interactive-examples}}
\sphinxAtStartPar
Let‚Äôs explore some of these signals using Python:

\PYG{n}{axes}\PYG{p}{[}\PYG{l+m+mi}{1}\PYG{p}{,}\PYG{l+m+mi}{1}\PYG{p}{]}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{set\PYGZus{}title}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{l+s+s1}{Even and Odd Components}\PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{p}{)}
\PYG{n}{axes}\PYG{p}{[}\PYG{l+m+mi}{1}\PYG{p}{,}\PYG{l+m+mi}{1}\PYG{p}{]}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{legend}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{p}{)}
\PYG{n}{axes}\PYG{p}{[}\PYG{l+m+mi}{1}\PYG{p}{,}\PYG{l+m+mi}{1}\PYG{p}{]}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{grid}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{k+kc}{True}\PYG{p}{)}
\PYG{n}{axes}\PYG{p}{[}\PYG{l+m+mi}{1}\PYG{p}{,}\PYG{l+m+mi}{1}\PYG{p}{]}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{set\PYGZus{}xlabel}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{l+s+s1}{Time (s)}\PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{p}{)}
\PYG{n}{axes}\PYG{p}{[}\PYG{l+m+mi}{1}\PYG{p}{,}\PYG{l+m+mi}{1}\PYG{p}{]}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{set\PYGZus{}ylabel}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{l+s+s1}{Amplitude}\PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{p}{)}

\PYG{n}{plt}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{tight\PYGZus{}layout}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{p}{)}
\PYG{n}{plt}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{show}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{p}{)}
\end{sphinxVerbatim}

\section{Energy and Power}
\label{\detokenize{aula_01/signals:energy-and-power}}
\sphinxAtStartPar
For a signal \(x(t)\), we define:

\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxstylestrong{Energy}:
\begin{equation*}
\begin{split}E = \int_{-\infty}^{\infty} |x(t)|^2 \, dt\end{split}
\end{equation*}

\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxstylestrong{Power} (for periodic signals):
\begin{equation*}
\begin{split}P = \frac{1}{T} \int_0^T |x(t)|^2 \, dt\end{split}
\end{equation*}

\sphinxAtStartPar
A signal is called:
\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxstylestrong{Energy signal} if \(E < \infty\) and \(P = 0\)

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxstylestrong{Power signal} if \(P < \infty\) and \(E = \infty\)

\end{itemize}


\section{Refer√™ncias}
\label{\detokenize{aula_01/signals:referencias}}
\sphinxstepscope


\chapter{Signals}
\label{\detokenize{aula_01/fft:signals}}\label{\detokenize{aula_01/fft::doc}}

\section{Definition of Signals}
\label{\detokenize{aula_01/fft:definition-of-signals}}
\sphinxAtStartPar
A \sphinxstylestrong{signal} is a function that carries information about a physical phenomenon. In the context of signals and systems, we typically deal with signals that vary with time.

\sphinxAtStartPar
Mathematically, a signal can be represented as:
\begin{equation*}
\begin{split}x(t) \quad \text{for continuous-time signals}\end{split}
\end{equation*}\begin{equation*}
\begin{split}x[n] \quad \text{for discrete-time signals}\end{split}
\end{equation*}
\sphinxAtStartPar
where:
\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
\(t\) is a continuous variable (time)

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
\(n\) is a discrete variable (sample number)

\end{itemize}


\section{Classification of Signals}
\label{\detokenize{aula_01/fft:classification-of-signals}}

\subsection{Continuous\sphinxhyphen{}time vs Discrete\sphinxhyphen{}time}
\label{\detokenize{aula_01/fft:continuous-time-vs-discrete-time}}
\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxstylestrong{Continuous\sphinxhyphen{}time signals} are defined for all values of time \(t\) in a continuous interval.

\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxstylestrong{Discrete\sphinxhyphen{}time signals} are defined only at discrete time instants, typically at regular intervals.


\subsection{Analog vs Digital}
\label{\detokenize{aula_01/fft:analog-vs-digital}}\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxstylestrong{Analog signals}: Continuous in both time and amplitude

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxstylestrong{Digital signals}: Discrete in both time and amplitude

\end{itemize}


\subsection{Periodic vs Aperiodic}
\label{\detokenize{aula_01/fft:periodic-vs-aperiodic}}
\sphinxAtStartPar
A signal \(x(t)\) is \sphinxstylestrong{periodic} if there exists a positive constant \(T\) such that:
\begin{equation*}
\begin{split}x(t) = x(t + T) \quad \text{for all } t\end{split}
\end{equation*}
\sphinxAtStartPar
The smallest such \(T\) is called the \sphinxstylestrong{fundamental period}.


\subsection{Even vs Odd}
\label{\detokenize{aula_01/fft:even-vs-odd}}
\sphinxAtStartPar
A signal is \sphinxstylestrong{even} if:
\begin{equation*}
\begin{split}x(t) = x(-t)\end{split}
\end{equation*}

\sphinxAtStartPar
A signal is \sphinxstylestrong{odd} if:
\begin{equation*}
\begin{split}x(t) = -x(-t)\end{split}
\end{equation*}


\section{Common Signals}
\label{\detokenize{aula_01/fft:common-signals}}

\subsection{Unit Step Function}
\label{\detokenize{aula_01/fft:unit-step-function}}\begin{equation*}
\begin{split}u(t) = \begin{cases}
1 & \text{if } t \geq 0 \\
0 & \text{if } t < 0
\end{cases}\end{split}
\end{equation*}

\subsection{Unit Impulse Function (Dirac Delta)}
\label{\detokenize{aula_01/fft:unit-impulse-function-dirac-delta}}\begin{equation*}
\begin{split}\delta(t) = \begin{cases}
\infty & \text{if } t = 0 \\
0 & \text{if } t \neq 0
\end{cases}\end{split}
\end{equation*}
\sphinxAtStartPar
with the property:
\begin{equation*}
\begin{split}\int_{-\infty}^{\infty} \delta(t) \, dt = 1\end{split}
\end{equation*}


\subsection{Sinusoidal Signals}
\label{\detokenize{aula_01/fft:sinusoidal-signals}}\begin{equation*}
\begin{split}x(t) = A \cos(\omega t + \phi)\end{split}
\end{equation*}
\sphinxAtStartPar
where:
\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
\(A\) is the amplitude

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
\(\omega\) is the angular frequency (rad/s)

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
\(\phi\) is the phase (rad)

\end{itemize}


\section{Interactive Examples}
\label{\detokenize{aula_01/fft:interactive-examples}}
\sphinxAtStartPar
Let‚Äôs explore some of these signals using Python:

\PYG{c+c1}{\PYGZsh{} RMS calculation function}
\PYG{k}{def}\PYG{+w}{ }\PYG{n+nf}{rms}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n}{x}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{:}
    \PYG{k}{return} \PYG{n}{np}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{sqrt}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n}{np}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{mean}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n}{np}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{square}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n}{x}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{)}

\PYG{c+c1}{\PYGZsh{} Peak\PYGZhy{}to\PYGZhy{}peak calculation function}
\PYG{k}{def}\PYG{+w}{ }\PYG{n+nf}{pk2pk}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n}{x}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{:}
    \PYG{k}{return} \PYG{n}{np}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{max}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n}{x}\PYG{p}{)} \PYG{o}{\PYGZhy{}} \PYG{n}{np}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{min}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n}{x}\PYG{p}{)}

\PYG{c+c1}{\PYGZsh{} Time vector}
\PYG{n}{t} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{n}{np}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{linspace}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{o}{\PYGZhy{}}\PYG{l+m+mi}{2}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{l+m+mi}{2}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{l+m+mi}{1000}\PYG{p}{)}

\PYG{c+c1}{\PYGZsh{} Create three base signals with different frequencies}
\PYG{n}{s1} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{n}{sinusoidal}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n}{t}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n}{A}\PYG{o}{=}\PYG{l+m+mi}{1}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n}{omega}\PYG{o}{=}\PYG{l+m+mi}{2}\PYG{o}{*}\PYG{n}{np}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{pi}\PYG{o}{*}\PYG{l+m+mi}{5}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n}{phi}\PYG{o}{=}\PYG{l+m+mi}{0}\PYG{p}{)}      \PYG{c+c1}{\PYGZsh{} 5 Hz}
\PYG{n}{s2} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{n}{sinusoidal}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n}{t}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n}{A}\PYG{o}{=}\PYG{l+m+mf}{0.8}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n}{omega}\PYG{o}{=}\PYG{l+m+mi}{2}\PYG{o}{*}\PYG{n}{np}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{pi}\PYG{o}{*}\PYG{l+m+mi}{15}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n}{phi}\PYG{o}{=}\PYG{n}{np}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{pi}\PYG{o}{/}\PYG{l+m+mi}{4}\PYG{p}{)}  \PYG{c+c1}{\PYGZsh{} 15 Hz, phase œÄ/4}
\PYG{n}{s3} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{n}{sinusoidal}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n}{t}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n}{A}\PYG{o}{=}\PYG{l+m+mf}{0.6}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n}{omega}\PYG{o}{=}\PYG{l+m+mi}{2}\PYG{o}{*}\PYG{n}{np}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{pi}\PYG{o}{*}\PYG{l+m+mi}{25}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n}{phi}\PYG{o}{=}\PYG{n}{np}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{pi}\PYG{o}{/}\PYG{l+m+mi}{2}\PYG{p}{)}  \PYG{c+c1}{\PYGZsh{} 25 Hz, phase œÄ/2}

\PYG{c+c1}{\PYGZsh{} Combination 1: All signals with original phases}
\PYG{n}{x1} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{n}{s1} \PYG{o}{+} \PYG{n}{s2} \PYG{o}{+} \PYG{n}{s3}

\PYG{c+c1}{\PYGZsh{} Combination 2: Same signals but with different phase relationships}
\PYG{n}{s1\PYGZus{}mod} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{n}{sinusoidal}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n}{t}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n}{A}\PYG{o}{=}\PYG{l+m+mi}{1}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n}{omega}\PYG{o}{=}\PYG{l+m+mi}{2}\PYG{o}{*}\PYG{n}{np}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{pi}\PYG{o}{*}\PYG{l+m+mi}{5}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n}{phi}\PYG{o}{=}\PYG{n}{np}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{pi}\PYG{o}{/}\PYG{l+m+mi}{3}\PYG{p}{)}
\PYG{n}{s2\PYGZus{}mod} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{n}{sinusoidal}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n}{t}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n}{A}\PYG{o}{=}\PYG{l+m+mf}{0.8}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n}{omega}\PYG{o}{=}\PYG{l+m+mi}{2}\PYG{o}{*}\PYG{n}{np}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{pi}\PYG{o}{*}\PYG{l+m+mi}{15}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n}{phi}\PYG{o}{=}\PYG{l+m+mi}{5}\PYG{o}{*}\PYG{n}{np}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{pi}\PYG{o}{/}\PYG{l+m+mi}{6}\PYG{p}{)}
\PYG{n}{s3\PYGZus{}mod} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{n}{sinusoidal}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n}{t}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n}{A}\PYG{o}{=}\PYG{l+m+mf}{0.6}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n}{omega}\PYG{o}{=}\PYG{l+m+mi}{2}\PYG{o}{*}\PYG{n}{np}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{pi}\PYG{o}{*}\PYG{l+m+mi}{25}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n}{phi}\PYG{o}{=}\PYG{l+m+mi}{2}\PYG{o}{*}\PYG{n}{np}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{pi}\PYG{o}{/}\PYG{l+m+mi}{3}\PYG{p}{)}
\PYG{n}{x2} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{n}{s1\PYGZus{}mod} \PYG{o}{+} \PYG{n}{s2\PYGZus{}mod} \PYG{o}{+} \PYG{n}{s3\PYGZus{}mod}

\PYG{c+c1}{\PYGZsh{} Calculate RMS and pk\PYGZhy{}pk values}
\PYG{n}{rms\PYGZus{}x1} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{n}{rms}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n}{x1}\PYG{p}{)}
\PYG{n}{rms\PYGZus{}x2} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{n}{rms}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n}{x2}\PYG{p}{)}
\PYG{n}{pkpk\PYGZus{}x1} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{n}{pk2pk}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n}{x1}\PYG{p}{)}
\PYG{n}{pkpk\PYGZus{}x2} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{n}{pk2pk}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n}{x2}\PYG{p}{)}

\PYG{c+c1}{\PYGZsh{} Calculate percent differences}
\PYG{n}{rms\PYGZus{}diff} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{n+nb}{abs}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n}{rms\PYGZus{}x1} \PYG{o}{\PYGZhy{}} \PYG{n}{rms\PYGZus{}x2}\PYG{p}{)}
\PYG{n}{pkpk\PYGZus{}diff} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{n+nb}{abs}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n}{pkpk\PYGZus{}x1} \PYG{o}{\PYGZhy{}} \PYG{n}{pkpk\PYGZus{}x2}\PYG{p}{)}
\PYG{n}{rms\PYGZus{}perc} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{l+m+mi}{100} \PYG{o}{*} \PYG{n}{rms\PYGZus{}diff} \PYG{o}{/} \PYG{n}{rms\PYGZus{}x1} \PYG{k}{if} \PYG{n}{rms\PYGZus{}x1} \PYG{o}{!=} \PYG{l+m+mi}{0} \PYG{k}{else} \PYG{l+m+mi}{0}
\PYG{n}{pkpk\PYGZus{}perc} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{l+m+mi}{100} \PYG{o}{*} \PYG{n}{pkpk\PYGZus{}diff} \PYG{o}{/} \PYG{n}{pkpk\PYGZus{}x1} \PYG{k}{if} \PYG{n}{pkpk\PYGZus{}x1} \PYG{o}{!=} \PYG{l+m+mi}{0} \PYG{k}{else} \PYG{l+m+mi}{0}

\PYG{n+nb}{print}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{l+s+sa}{f}\PYG{l+s+s2}{\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{l+s+s2}{RMS of signal x1: }\PYG{l+s+si}{\PYGZob{}}\PYG{n}{rms\PYGZus{}x1}\PYG{l+s+si}{:}\PYG{l+s+s2}{.3f}\PYG{l+s+si}{\PYGZcb{}}\PYG{l+s+s2}{\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{p}{)}
\PYG{n+nb}{print}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{l+s+sa}{f}\PYG{l+s+s2}{\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{l+s+s2}{RMS of signal x2: }\PYG{l+s+si}{\PYGZob{}}\PYG{n}{rms\PYGZus{}x2}\PYG{l+s+si}{:}\PYG{l+s+s2}{.3f}\PYG{l+s+si}{\PYGZcb{}}\PYG{l+s+s2}{\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{p}{)}
\PYG{n+nb}{print}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{l+s+sa}{f}\PYG{l+s+s2}{\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{l+s+s2}{Pk\PYGZhy{}Pk of signal x1: }\PYG{l+s+si}{\PYGZob{}}\PYG{n}{pkpk\PYGZus{}x1}\PYG{l+s+si}{:}\PYG{l+s+s2}{.3f}\PYG{l+s+si}{\PYGZcb{}}\PYG{l+s+s2}{\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{p}{)}
\PYG{n+nb}{print}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{l+s+sa}{f}\PYG{l+s+s2}{\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{l+s+s2}{Pk\PYGZhy{}Pk of signal x2: }\PYG{l+s+si}{\PYGZob{}}\PYG{n}{pkpk\PYGZus{}x2}\PYG{l+s+si}{:}\PYG{l+s+s2}{.3f}\PYG{l+s+si}{\PYGZcb{}}\PYG{l+s+s2}{\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{p}{)}
\PYG{n+nb}{print}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{l+s+sa}{f}\PYG{l+s+s2}{\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{l+s+s2}{Absolute difference in RMS: }\PYG{l+s+si}{\PYGZob{}}\PYG{n}{rms\PYGZus{}diff}\PYG{l+s+si}{:}\PYG{l+s+s2}{.3f}\PYG{l+s+si}{\PYGZcb{}}\PYG{l+s+s2}{\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{p}{)}
\PYG{n+nb}{print}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{l+s+sa}{f}\PYG{l+s+s2}{\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{l+s+s2}{Percentual difference in RMS: }\PYG{l+s+si}{\PYGZob{}}\PYG{n}{rms\PYGZus{}perc}\PYG{l+s+si}{:}\PYG{l+s+s2}{.2f}\PYG{l+s+si}{\PYGZcb{}}\PYG{l+s+s2}{\PYGZpc{}}\PYG{l+s+s2}{\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{p}{)}
\PYG{n+nb}{print}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{l+s+sa}{f}\PYG{l+s+s2}{\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{l+s+s2}{Absolute difference in Pk\PYGZhy{}Pk: }\PYG{l+s+si}{\PYGZob{}}\PYG{n}{pkpk\PYGZus{}diff}\PYG{l+s+si}{:}\PYG{l+s+s2}{.3f}\PYG{l+s+si}{\PYGZcb{}}\PYG{l+s+s2}{\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{p}{)}
\PYG{n+nb}{print}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{l+s+sa}{f}\PYG{l+s+s2}{\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{l+s+s2}{Percentual difference in Pk\PYGZhy{}Pk: }\PYG{l+s+si}{\PYGZob{}}\PYG{n}{pkpk\PYGZus{}perc}\PYG{l+s+si}{:}\PYG{l+s+s2}{.2f}\PYG{l+s+si}{\PYGZcb{}}\PYG{l+s+s2}{\PYGZpc{}}\PYG{l+s+s2}{\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{p}{)}

\PYG{c+c1}{\PYGZsh{} Compute FFTs}
\PYG{n}{X1} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{n}{np}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{fft}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{fft}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n}{x1}\PYG{p}{)}
\PYG{n}{X2} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{n}{np}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{fft}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{fft}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n}{x2}\PYG{p}{)}
\PYG{n}{freqs} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{n}{np}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{fft}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{fftfreq}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n+nb}{len}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n}{t}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n}{d}\PYG{o}{=}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n}{t}\PYG{p}{[}\PYG{l+m+mi}{1}\PYG{p}{]}\PYG{o}{\PYGZhy{}}\PYG{n}{t}\PYG{p}{[}\PYG{l+m+mi}{0}\PYG{p}{]}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{)}

\PYG{c+c1}{\PYGZsh{} Only plot the positive frequencies}
\PYG{n}{idx} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{n}{np}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{argsort}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n}{freqs}\PYG{p}{)}
\PYG{n}{freqs\PYGZus{}sorted} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{n}{freqs}\PYG{p}{[}\PYG{n}{idx}\PYG{p}{]}
\PYG{n}{X1\PYGZus{}sorted} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{n}{X1}\PYG{p}{[}\PYG{n}{idx}\PYG{p}{]}
\PYG{n}{X2\PYGZus{}sorted} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{n}{X2}\PYG{p}{[}\PYG{n}{idx}\PYG{p}{]}
\PYG{n}{pos\PYGZus{}mask} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{n}{freqs\PYGZus{}sorted} \PYG{o}{\PYGZgt{}}\PYG{o}{=} \PYG{l+m+mi}{0}

\PYG{c+c1}{\PYGZsh{} Create a comprehensive visualization}
\PYG{n}{fig}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n}{axes} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{n}{plt}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{subplots}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{l+m+mi}{3}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{l+m+mi}{2}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n}{figsize}\PYG{o}{=}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{l+m+mi}{15}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{l+m+mi}{12}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{)}

\PYG{n+nb}{slice} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{l+m+mi}{200}  \PYG{c+c1}{\PYGZsh{} Show more of the signal for better visualization}

\noindent\sphinxincludegraphics{{e99fd98e72104b3692e1c1b9d966899a0fcdd303ea6fc82515998bd41381b089}.png}

\begin{sphinxVerbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
============================================================
ANALYSIS:
============================================================
Both signals x1 and x2 contain the same frequency components:
\PYGZhy{} 5 Hz (fundamental frequency)
\PYGZhy{} 15 Hz (third harmonic)
\PYGZhy{} 25 Hz (fifth harmonic)

The FFT magnitude spectra are nearly identical because:
\PYGZhy{} Both signals have the same frequency content
\PYGZhy{} Only the phases of individual components differ
\PYGZhy{} FFT magnitude is independent of phase information

However, the RMS and pk\PYGZhy{}pk values are different because:
\PYGZhy{} Different phase relationships cause constructive/destructive interference
\PYGZhy{} RMS depends on the instantaneous power, which varies with phase
\PYGZhy{} Pk\PYGZhy{}Pk (peak\PYGZhy{}to\PYGZhy{}peak) value also depends on phase relationships
\PYGZhy{} This demonstrates how phase affects signal energy distribution and amplitude range

Percentual difference in RMS: 0.11\PYGZpc{}
Percentual difference in Pk\PYGZhy{}Pk: 22.60\PYGZpc{}
\end{sphinxVerbatim}

\end{sphinxuseclass}
\end{sphinxuseclass}

\begin{sphinxuseclass}{cell_input}

\PYG{k+kn}{import}\PYG{+w}{ }\PYG{n+nn}{numpy}\PYG{+w}{ }\PYG{k}{as}\PYG{+w}{ }\PYG{n+nn}{np}
\PYG{k+kn}{import}\PYG{+w}{ }\PYG{n+nn}{matplotlib}\PYG{n+nn}{.}\PYG{n+nn}{pyplot}\PYG{+w}{ }\PYG{k}{as}\PYG{+w}{ }\PYG{n+nn}{plt}

\PYG{c+c1}{\PYGZsh{} Sinusoidal signal}
\PYG{k}{def}\PYG{+w}{ }\PYG{n+nf}{sinusoidal}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n}{t}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n}{A}\PYG{o}{=}\PYG{l+m+mi}{1}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n}{omega}\PYG{o}{=}\PYG{l+m+mi}{2}\PYG{o}{*}\PYG{n}{np}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{pi}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n}{phi}\PYG{o}{=}\PYG{l+m+mi}{0}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{:}
    \PYG{k}{return} \PYG{n}{A} \PYG{o}{*} \PYG{n}{np}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{cos}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n}{omega} \PYG{o}{*} \PYG{n}{t} \PYG{o}{+} \PYG{n}{phi}\PYG{p}{)}

\PYG{c+c1}{\PYGZsh{} RMS calculation function}
\PYG{k}{def}\PYG{+w}{ }\PYG{n+nf}{rms}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n}{x}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{:}
    \PYG{k}{return} \PYG{n}{np}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{sqrt}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n}{np}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{mean}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n}{np}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{square}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n}{x}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{)}

\PYG{c+c1}{\PYGZsh{} Time vector}
\PYG{n}{t} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{n}{np}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{linspace}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{o}{\PYGZhy{}}\PYG{l+m+mi}{2}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{l+m+mi}{2}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{l+m+mi}{1000}\PYG{p}{)}
\PYG{c+c1}{\PYGZsh{} Two signals with same frequency and amplitude, but different phases}
\PYG{n}{y1} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{n}{sinusoidal}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n}{t}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n}{A}\PYG{o}{=}\PYG{l+m+mi}{1}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n}{omega}\PYG{o}{=}\PYG{l+m+mi}{2}\PYG{o}{*}\PYG{n}{np}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{pi}\PYG{o}{*}\PYG{l+m+mi}{10}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n}{phi}\PYG{o}{=}\PYG{l+m+mi}{0}\PYG{p}{)}
\PYG{n}{y2} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{n}{sinusoidal}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n}{t}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n}{A}\PYG{o}{=}\PYG{l+m+mi}{1}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n}{omega}\PYG{o}{=}\PYG{l+m+mi}{2}\PYG{o}{*}\PYG{n}{np}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{pi}\PYG{o}{*}\PYG{l+m+mi}{30}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n}{phi}\PYG{o}{=}\PYG{n}{np}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{pi}\PYG{o}{/}\PYG{l+m+mi}{2}\PYG{p}{)}
\PYG{n}{y3} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{n}{sinusoidal}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n}{t}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n}{A}\PYG{o}{=}\PYG{l+m+mi}{1}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n}{omega}\PYG{o}{=}\PYG{l+m+mi}{2}\PYG{o}{*}\PYG{n}{np}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{pi}\PYG{o}{*}\PYG{l+m+mi}{30}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n}{phi}\PYG{o}{=}\PYG{o}{\PYGZhy{}}\PYG{n}{np}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{pi}\PYG{o}{/}\PYG{l+m+mi}{2}\PYG{p}{)}

\PYG{n}{x1} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{n}{y1} \PYG{o}{+} \PYG{n}{y2}
\PYG{n}{x2} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{n}{y1} \PYG{o}{+} \PYG{n}{y3}

\PYG{c+c1}{\PYGZsh{} Compute FFTs}
\PYG{n}{X1} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{n}{np}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{fft}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{fft}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n}{x1}\PYG{p}{)}
\PYG{n}{X2} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{n}{np}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{fft}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{fft}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n}{x2}\PYG{p}{)}
\PYG{n}{freqs} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{n}{np}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{fft}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{fftfreq}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n+nb}{len}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n}{t}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n}{d}\PYG{o}{=}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n}{t}\PYG{p}{[}\PYG{l+m+mi}{1}\PYG{p}{]}\PYG{o}{\PYGZhy{}}\PYG{n}{t}\PYG{p}{[}\PYG{l+m+mi}{0}\PYG{p}{]}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{)}

\PYG{c+c1}{\PYGZsh{} Only plot the positive frequencies}
\PYG{n}{idx} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{n}{np}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{argsort}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n}{freqs}\PYG{p}{)}
\PYG{n}{freqs\PYGZus{}sorted} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{n}{freqs}\PYG{p}{[}\PYG{n}{idx}\PYG{p}{]}
\PYG{n}{X1\PYGZus{}sorted} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{n}{X1}\PYG{p}{[}\PYG{n}{idx}\PYG{p}{]}
\PYG{n}{X2\PYGZus{}sorted} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{n}{X2}\PYG{p}{[}\PYG{n}{idx}\PYG{p}{]}
\PYG{n}{pos\PYGZus{}mask} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{n}{freqs\PYGZus{}sorted} \PYG{o}{\PYGZgt{}}\PYG{o}{=} \PYG{l+m+mi}{0}

\PYG{c+c1}{\PYGZsh{} Create a 3\PYGZhy{}row, 2\PYGZhy{}column grid: }
\PYG{c+c1}{\PYGZsh{} (1,1) and (1,2): time domain (merged)}
\PYG{c+c1}{\PYGZsh{} (2,1): FFT magnitude of x1, (2,2): FFT magnitude of x2}
\PYG{c+c1}{\PYGZsh{} (3,1): FFT phase of x1, (3,2): FFT phase of x2}

\PYG{n}{fig}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n}{axes} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{n}{plt}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{subplots}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{l+m+mi}{3}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{l+m+mi}{2}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n}{figsize}\PYG{o}{=}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{l+m+mi}{14}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{l+m+mi}{14}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{)}

\PYG{n+nb}{slice} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{l+m+mi}{100}

\PYG{c+c1}{\PYGZsh{} Calculate RMS values for the time domain signals (over the full signal)}
\PYG{n}{rms\PYGZus{}x1} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{n}{rms}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n}{x1}\PYG{p}{)}
\PYG{n}{rms\PYGZus{}x2} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{n}{rms}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n}{x2}\PYG{p}{)}

\PYG{c+c1}{\PYGZsh{} Demonstration:}
\PYG{n+nb}{print}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{l+s+s2}{\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{l+s+s2}{Notice that the FFT magnitude spectra of the two signals are identical,}\PYG{l+s+s2}{\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{p}{)}
\PYG{n+nb}{print}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{l+s+s2}{\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{l+s+s2}{even though the time\PYGZhy{}domain signals are different due to their phase.}\PYG{l+s+s2}{\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{p}{)}
\PYG{n+nb}{print}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{l+s+s2}{\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{l+s+s2}{This shows that the FFT magnitude does not retain phase information.}\PYG{l+s+s2}{\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{p}{)}

\begin{sphinxuseclass}{cell_output}
\noindent\sphinxincludegraphics{{517ae75de7792e572ba1e1c672a6e686256539f99b92c75f9ad43a6372f864e8}.png}

\begin{sphinxVerbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
Notice that the FFT magnitude spectra of the two signals are identical,
even though the time\PYGZhy{}domain signals are different due to their phase.
This shows that the FFT magnitude does not retain phase information.
\end{sphinxVerbatim}

\end{sphinxuseclass}
\end{sphinxuseclass}
\begin{sphinxuseclass}{cell}
\begin{sphinxuseclass}{cell_input}
\begin{sphinxVerbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
\PYG{k+kn}{import}\PYG{+w}{ }\PYG{n+nn}{numpy}\PYG{+w}{ }\PYG{k}{as}\PYG{+w}{ }\PYG{n+nn}{np}
\PYG{k+kn}{import}\PYG{+w}{ }\PYG{n+nn}{matplotlib}\PYG{n+nn}{.}\PYG{n+nn}{pyplot}\PYG{+w}{ }\PYG{k}{as}\PYG{+w}{ }\PYG{n+nn}{plt}

\PYG{c+c1}{\PYGZsh{} Sinusoidal signal}
\PYG{k}{def}\PYG{+w}{ }\PYG{n+nf}{sinusoidal}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n}{t}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n}{A}\PYG{o}{=}\PYG{l+m+mi}{1}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n}{omega}\PYG{o}{=}\PYG{l+m+mi}{2}\PYG{o}{*}\PYG{n}{np}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{pi}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n}{phi}\PYG{o}{=}\PYG{l+m+mi}{0}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{:}
    \PYG{k}{return} \PYG{n}{A} \PYG{o}{*} \PYG{n}{np}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{cos}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n}{omega} \PYG{o}{*} \PYG{n}{t} \PYG{o}{+} \PYG{n}{phi}\PYG{p}{)}

\PYG{c+c1}{\PYGZsh{} RMS calculation function}
\PYG{k}{def}\PYG{+w}{ }\PYG{n+nf}{rms}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n}{x}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{:}
    \PYG{k}{return} \PYG{n}{np}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{sqrt}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n}{np}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{mean}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n}{np}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{square}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n}{x}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{)}

\PYG{c+c1}{\PYGZsh{} Time vector}
\PYG{n}{t} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{n}{np}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{linspace}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{o}{\PYGZhy{}}\PYG{l+m+mi}{2}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{l+m+mi}{2}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{l+m+mi}{1000}\PYG{p}{)}

\PYG{c+c1}{\PYGZsh{} Scenario: Two signals, each a sum of two sinusoids with the same frequencies,}
\PYG{c+c1}{\PYGZsh{} but with different amplitude combinations, so that their FFT magnitudes are similar}
\PYG{c+c1}{\PYGZsh{} (same peaks at the same frequencies), but their RMS values are different.}

\PYG{c+c1}{\PYGZsh{} Frequencies}
\PYG{n}{f1} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{l+m+mi}{10}  \PYG{c+c1}{\PYGZsh{} Hz}
\PYG{n}{f2} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{l+m+mi}{30}  \PYG{c+c1}{\PYGZsh{} Hz}

\PYG{c+c1}{\PYGZsh{} Signal 1: both sinusoids with amplitude 1}
\PYG{n}{y1} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{n}{sinusoidal}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n}{t}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n}{A}\PYG{o}{=}\PYG{l+m+mi}{1}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n}{omega}\PYG{o}{=}\PYG{l+m+mi}{2}\PYG{o}{*}\PYG{n}{np}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{pi}\PYG{o}{*}\PYG{n}{f1}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n}{phi}\PYG{o}{=}\PYG{l+m+mi}{0}\PYG{p}{)}
\PYG{n}{y2} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{n}{sinusoidal}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n}{t}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n}{A}\PYG{o}{=}\PYG{l+m+mi}{1}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n}{omega}\PYG{o}{=}\PYG{l+m+mi}{2}\PYG{o}{*}\PYG{n}{np}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{pi}\PYG{o}{*}\PYG{n}{f2}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n}{phi}\PYG{o}{=}\PYG{l+m+mi}{0}\PYG{p}{)}
\PYG{n}{x1} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{n}{y1} \PYG{o}{+} \PYG{n}{y2}

\PYG{c+c1}{\PYGZsh{} Signal 2: both sinusoids with amplitude sqrt(2), but divided by sqrt(2) to keep the FFT peaks at the same height}
\PYG{c+c1}{\PYGZsh{} (since FFT magnitude is proportional to amplitude, but RMS is sensitive to the sum of squares)}
\PYG{n}{y1b} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{n}{sinusoidal}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n}{t}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n}{A}\PYG{o}{=}\PYG{n}{np}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{sqrt}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{l+m+mi}{2}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n}{omega}\PYG{o}{=}\PYG{l+m+mi}{2}\PYG{o}{*}\PYG{n}{np}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{pi}\PYG{o}{*}\PYG{n}{f1}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n}{phi}\PYG{o}{=}\PYG{l+m+mi}{0}\PYG{p}{)}
\PYG{n}{y2b} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{n}{sinusoidal}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n}{t}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n}{A}\PYG{o}{=}\PYG{n}{np}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{sqrt}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{l+m+mi}{2}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n}{omega}\PYG{o}{=}\PYG{l+m+mi}{2}\PYG{o}{*}\PYG{n}{np}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{pi}\PYG{o}{*}\PYG{n}{f2}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n}{phi}\PYG{o}{=}\PYG{l+m+mi}{0}\PYG{p}{)}
\PYG{n}{x2} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n}{y1b} \PYG{o}{+} \PYG{n}{y2b}\PYG{p}{)} \PYG{o}{/} \PYG{n}{np}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{sqrt}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{l+m+mi}{2}\PYG{p}{)}

\PYG{c+c1}{\PYGZsh{} Compute FFTs}
\PYG{n}{X1} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{n}{np}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{fft}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{fft}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n}{x1}\PYG{p}{)}
\PYG{n}{X2} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{n}{np}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{fft}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{fft}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n}{x2}\PYG{p}{)}
\PYG{n}{freqs} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{n}{np}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{fft}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{fftfreq}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n+nb}{len}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n}{t}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n}{d}\PYG{o}{=}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n}{t}\PYG{p}{[}\PYG{l+m+mi}{1}\PYG{p}{]}\PYG{o}{\PYGZhy{}}\PYG{n}{t}\PYG{p}{[}\PYG{l+m+mi}{0}\PYG{p}{]}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{)}

\PYG{c+c1}{\PYGZsh{} Only plot the positive frequencies}
\PYG{n}{idx} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{n}{np}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{argsort}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n}{freqs}\PYG{p}{)}
\PYG{n}{freqs\PYGZus{}sorted} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{n}{freqs}\PYG{p}{[}\PYG{n}{idx}\PYG{p}{]}
\PYG{n}{X1\PYGZus{}sorted} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{n}{X1}\PYG{p}{[}\PYG{n}{idx}\PYG{p}{]}
\PYG{n}{X2\PYGZus{}sorted} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{n}{X2}\PYG{p}{[}\PYG{n}{idx}\PYG{p}{]}
\PYG{n}{pos\PYGZus{}mask} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{n}{freqs\PYGZus{}sorted} \PYG{o}{\PYGZgt{}}\PYG{o}{=} \PYG{l+m+mi}{0}

\PYG{c+c1}{\PYGZsh{} Create a 3\PYGZhy{}row, 2\PYGZhy{}column grid: }
\PYG{c+c1}{\PYGZsh{} (1,1) and (1,2): time domain (merged)}
\PYG{c+c1}{\PYGZsh{} (2,1): FFT magnitude of x1, (2,2): FFT magnitude of x2}
\PYG{c+c1}{\PYGZsh{} (3,1): FFT phase of x1, (3,2): FFT phase of x2}

\PYG{n}{fig}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n}{axes} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{n}{plt}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{subplots}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{l+m+mi}{3}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{l+m+mi}{2}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n}{figsize}\PYG{o}{=}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{l+m+mi}{14}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{l+m+mi}{14}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{)}

\PYG{n+nb}{slice} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{l+m+mi}{100}

\PYG{c+c1}{\PYGZsh{} Calculate RMS values for the time domain signals (over the full signal)}
\PYG{n}{rms\PYGZus{}x1} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{n}{rms}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n}{x1}\PYG{p}{)}
\PYG{n}{rms\PYGZus{}x2} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{n}{rms}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n}{x2}\PYG{p}{)}

\PYG{c+c1}{\PYGZsh{} First row: time domain, left: x1, right: x2}
\PYG{n}{axes}\PYG{p}{[}\PYG{l+m+mi}{0}\PYG{p}{,}\PYG{l+m+mi}{0}\PYG{p}{]}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{plot}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n}{t}\PYG{p}{[}\PYG{p}{:}\PYG{n+nb}{slice}\PYG{p}{]}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n}{x1}\PYG{p}{[}\PYG{p}{:}\PYG{n+nb}{slice}\PYG{p}{]}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n}{label}\PYG{o}{=}\PYG{l+s+sa}{f}\PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{l+s+s1}{x1: 1*cos(2œÄ}\PYG{l+s+si}{\PYGZob{}}\PYG{n}{f1}\PYG{l+s+si}{\PYGZcb{}}\PYG{l+s+s1}{t)+1*cos(2œÄ}\PYG{l+s+si}{\PYGZob{}}\PYG{n}{f2}\PYG{l+s+si}{\PYGZcb{}}\PYG{l+s+s1}{t)}\PYG{l+s+s1}{\PYGZsq{}}\PYG{p}{)}

\PYG{c+c1}{\PYGZsh{} Demonstration:}
\PYG{n+nb}{print}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{l+s+s2}{\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{l+s+s2}{Notice that the FFT magnitude spectra of the two signals are very similar,}\PYG{l+s+s2}{\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{p}{)}
\PYG{n+nb}{print}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{l+s+s2}{\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{l+s+s2}{even though the time\PYGZhy{}domain signals have different RMS values.}\PYG{l+s+s2}{\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{p}{)}
\PYG{n+nb}{print}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{l+s+s2}{\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{l+s+s2}{This shows that signals with similar frequency content (FFT) can have different energy (RMS).}\PYG{l+s+s2}{\PYGZdq{}}\PYG{p}{)}
\end{sphinxVerbatim}

\end{sphinxuseclass}
\begin{sphinxuseclass}{cell_output}
\noindent\sphinxincludegraphics{{949b2a80cfba7b2e1af7c8323336bb2b97e0bce6e55210392c407841773dbf56}.png}

\begin{sphinxVerbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
Notice that the FFT magnitude spectra of the two signals are very similar,
even though the time\PYGZhy{}domain signals have different RMS values.
This shows that signals with similar frequency content (FFT) can have different energy (RMS).
\end{sphinxVerbatim}

\end{sphinxuseclass}
\end{sphinxuseclass}

\section{Energy and Power}
\label{\detokenize{aula_01/fft:energy-and-power}}
\sphinxAtStartPar
For a signal \(x(t)\), we define:

\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxstylestrong{Energy}:
\begin{equation*}
\begin{split}E = \int_{-\infty}^{\infty} |x(t)|^2 \, dt\end{split}
\end{equation*}

\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxstylestrong{Power} (for periodic signals):
\begin{equation*}
\begin{split}P = \frac{1}{T} \int_0^T |x(t)|^2 \, dt\end{split}
\end{equation*}

\sphinxAtStartPar
A signal is called:
\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxstylestrong{Energy signal} if \(E < \infty\) and \(P = 0\)

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxstylestrong{Power signal} if \(P < \infty\) and \(E = \infty\)

\end{itemize}
